<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 798, 92]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistances of combinations of resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 871, 123]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1. The circuit has been set up for you.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 128, 715, 300]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 316, 534, 335]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 348, 146, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 299, 365]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 378, 183, 396]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 378, 494, 397]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 408, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
<form>\(I_{1} =\) .................................................... A [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 440, 181, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 440, 841, 460]]<|/det|>
Measure the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{1}\) across resistors \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{A}}\) and \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{B}}\) in series.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 501, 920, 521]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{1} = .................................................... V [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 533, 180, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 533, 336, 552]]<|/det|>
Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 562, 900, 583]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of the combination of resistors in series. Use the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 586, 536, 621]]<|/det|>
\[R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 625, 329, 644]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 655, 920, 675]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 687, 148, 706]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 687, 831, 707]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter. Connect resistor \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{C}}\) in parallel with resistors \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{A}}\) and \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 718, 665, 737]]<|/det|>
Do **not** change the series combination of resistors \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{A}}\) and \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 749, 710, 768]]<|/det|>
Connect the voltmeter across the combination of all three resistors.

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 648, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length \(f\) of a lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 579, 121]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 128, 892, 288]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 305, 532, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 336, 144, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 336, 755, 355]]<|/det|>
Place the screen a distance \(D = 75.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 368, 170, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 368, 920, 401]]<|/det|>
Place the lens between the object and the screen so that the lens is close to the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 414, 173, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 414, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
Move the lens away from the object until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 446, 180, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 446, 920, 479]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the distance \(u\) between the centre of the lens and the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 460, 920, 479]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 491, 180, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 491, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 508, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 539, 180, 556]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 539, 868, 556]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[468, 562, 529, 591]]<|/det|>
\[f = \frac{uv}{D}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 586, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 616, 146, 634]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 616, 774, 634]]<|/det|>
Place the screen at a distance \(D = 85.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 648, 170, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 648, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
Place the lens between the object and the screen so that the lens is close to the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 694, 175, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 694, 757, 712]]<|/det|>
Move the lens until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 725, 920, 758]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the distance \(u\) between the centre of the lens and the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 771, 920, 803]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 828, 89]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 97, 529, 123]]<|/det|> \[f = \frac{uv}{D}.\] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 134, 541, 151]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 165, 717, 243]]<|/det|>

The gradient of the graph is numerically equal to the focal length. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 596, 180, 615]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 596, 813, 613]]<|/det|> Suggest a suitable number of sets of readings that the student should take. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 625, 920, 644]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 657, 181, 675]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 656, 920, 689]]<|/det|> Explain briefly how this graphical method can give a more accurate value for the focal length. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 794, 920, 812]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 827, 920, 845]]<|/det|> [Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 390, 88]]<|/det|>
A student investigates insulators.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 834, 120]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to list insulating discs in order from best insulator to worst insulator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 536, 151]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 420, 182]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 185, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 196, 603, 212]]<|/det|>
five discs made from different insulating materials

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 319, 227]]<|/det|>
a thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 228, 304, 243]]<|/det|>
a stop-watch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 504, 259]]<|/det|>
a heated metal cylinder (see Fig. 4.1)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 258, 771, 275]]<|/det|>
a second metal cylinder with a hole for the thermometer (see Fig. 4.1).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 285, 784, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 432, 532, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 463, 908, 481]]<|/det|>
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 495, 324, 512]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 526, 655, 544]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 558, 569, 574]]<|/det|>
state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 588, 918, 621]]<|/det|>
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 635, 720, 652]]<|/det|>
explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.
